item.title: Synthetic Disinformation
item.description: In this multi-part research project, Dr. Sarah Kreps and I studied how synthetic (AI-generated) disinformation can deceive the public and masquerade as reliable, human-written news. Wrote “All The News That’s Fit to Fabricate: A Study of Synthetic Disinformation” with Dr. Kreps and Miles Brundage (forthcoming in the Journal of Experimental Political Science). Co-authored “Not Your Father’s Bots” in Foreign Affairs with Dr. Kreps. Co-authored “Taking GPT-2 head-to-head with the New York Times” in Brookings’ TechStream with Dr.

item.title: Politiwatch
item.description: Politiwatch is a non-profit that technology to promote political accountability, digital rights, and social awareness. I founded Politiwatch as a way to distance myself from some of my more controversial projects. (They weren’t that controversial, but I didn’t feel comfortable putting my name on them.) If you find the work I do as Politiwatch impactful, please consider donating. Politiwatch’s sponsors include Google (via their Google for Nonprofits program), Microsoft (though their nonprofit grants program), ProtonMail, and DigitalOcean.

item.title: WhoAreMyRepresentatives
item.description: WhoAreMyRepresentatives.org (WAMR) is a simple tool to look up the government representatives for any U.S. address. It pulls its information from the Google Civics API and the OpenSecrets API. Used more than 1 million times and maintains steady traffic. Displayed in the top spot of Hacker News for over nine hours. Featured on ProductHunt. Hit the front page of Reddit (5k+ upvotes). Received an (informal) invitation to visit Google. Shared by Dave Lee, Colin Wright, HANA, Mike Elgan, and others.

item.title: PolitiTweet
item.description: PolitiTweet preserves the public record by archiving the tweets of major public figures and prominently displaying those that have been deleted. View the site at polititweet.org or read the source code on GitHub. Media Coverage Nightly News with Lester Holt: “Wide Range of Celebrities Accidentally Tweeted Russian Propaganda During 2016 Election” — “Famous Twitter users with big followers, from Ivanka Trump to comedians Trevor Noah and Sarah Silverman, inadvertently shared tweets that came from accounts linked to Russia, according to social media tracker PolitiTweet.
